Graphical abstract Carbenes are key precursors for various transformations and are applied broadly in the synthesis of complex molecules and drug. Typically, such transformations require expensive metal and complex ligands, leading to a vigorous reaction system and trace metal residues. Herein, we report copper-modified silica microspheres (SM-b) as heterogeneous catalyst in the insertion reaction of diazo compounds with carbazole and silanes. Under this strategy, the optimal SM-b catalyst can prevent the reaction from being too vigorous and can be reused in continuous reactions. Furthermore, gram-scale and catalyst recycling reactions have been proven as the potential industrial applications of the SM-b catalysts. Inductively coupled plasma analysis revealed a residual copper content of only 6.25 ppm in the reaction solution and no detectable copper in the final product, indicating that the residual metal content of the product is far below the FDA-imposed limit of metal impurities. Keywords Silica microsphere Copper modified N–H insertion Si–H insertion No metal residue Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Diazo compounds represent ideal reaction substrates to generate different transformations, including carbene insertion reaction, cyclopropenation reaction and Wolff rearrangement [1–4]. Many researchers and communities have explored a series of advanced and convenient transformation methods due to the high reactivity of diazo compounds. Among them, metal salts or complexes, including Rh [5–7], Pd [8–11], Cu [12–15], Fe [16–18], Ru [19], and Ag [20], engage reactions, which have established important methodologies for the easy construction of C–C and C–X bonds [21]. In these cases, nitrogen removal from diazo compounds to form active metal carbenes is crucial for efficient reactions. However, active carbene species are unstable and explosive owing to their electronic and steric nature [22,23], even though nitrogen release compensates the driving force for generating energetically unfavorable metal carbene [24], which means that such reaction rate is hard to control and many side reactions occur (Scheme 1 a). N-substituted carbazoles and organosilanes are essential structural motifs in drugs and biologically active molecules and serve as potential intermediates of anti-cancer agents (Fig. 1 ) [25–30]. In 2017, Vranken et al. reported the catalytic system comprising Pd and PyBOX ligands for carbene N–H insertion of carbazole. Giorgio and Ruben described carbene Si–H bond insertions catalyzed by Cu(I) and macrocyclic pyridine-containing ligands (Scheme 1b). In these works, expensive metal catalysts and complex ligands are requisite. However, the frequent use of transition metal catalysts causes trace metal impurities, which can be unfavorable and problematic [31–33]. In addition, trace-metal levels in active pharmaceutical ingredients have been regulated by many regulatory authorities, such as the United States Food and Drug Administration, International Conference Harmonization, and the Canadian Drug and Health Agency [34]. Therefore, a green and effective synthesis method for N-substituted carbazoles and organosilanes that avoids metal residues remains highly desirable. Heterogeneous catalysts have gained significant attention due to their various advantages, including ease of product preparation, isolation, and catalyst reuse [35–37]. In 2015, Díaz-Requejo, Pérez, and Pericàs reported the use of a recyclable and highly efficient heterogenized copper complex, PS-TTM-Cu(NCMe)[PF6], for carbene transfer reactions [38]. In 2021, Yasukawa and Kobayashi et al. described the use of Rh nanoparticle catalysts supported on N-doped carbon (NCI-Rh) as solid ligands for the insertion of carbenes into N − H bonds (Scheme 1c) [39]. In our previous work, we reported a green and reusable surface-modified sewage sludge (SW) as a heterogeneous catalyst for O–H and N–H bond insertion reactions without the need for additional ligands and metals (Scheme 1d) [40,41]. While the sewage sludge catalyst is environmentally friendly, it is challenging to control its sedimentation processes and ensure isotropy, leading to the occurrence of numerous side reactions and metal leaching. In retrospect, silicon dioxide is a non-toxic, pollution-free material with high chemical stability and mechanical strength; thus, it is widely applied as a carrier in drug delivery [42–44]. However, few works have used silica dioxide as a catalyst carrier for organic synthesis. Baller et al. developed stable and reusable Ni– and Pd–based silica powders as catalysts for hydrogenation reaction [45,46], but in the preparation of catalyst, high-temperature is requisite to maintain the catalyst stability, which raise the cost and is hard to apply on large-scale. Recently, silica microspheres (SMs) have been applied in sensors, photosensitive emulsion, and medicine [47–50]. SMs show characteristics of isotropy and low fluid resistance [51,52], demonstrating their potential as carrier for heterogeneous catalysts. Therefore, the development of easily prepared and stable SMs as a carrier for obtaining a heterogeneous catalyst is still appealing and meaningful. Given that N-substituted carbazoles and organosilanes have diverse pharmaceutical activities, achieving green and effective synthesis and avoiding trace metal residues are important pursuit of sustainable development. Herein, we design several metal-modified SM catalysts by surface-modification. Metal-modified SM can be applied as catalysts to achieve N–H insertion and Si–H insertion reactions without the need of ligand participation, generating products in good to excellent yields (Scheme 1e) Besides, the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and X-ray diffraction (XRD) experiments were performed to verify the modified substance dispersion of SMs. Subsequently, gram-scale reaction and catalyst recycling experiments were conducted to prove the potential dispersion of modified substances on SMs. Finally, the inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis was carried out and the results indicated that the residual metal content in the reaction solution was as low as 6.25 ppm, and no metal residues were detected in the target product. These phenomena confirm that our approach meets the stringent requirements for metal impurity limits set by the FDA, thereby ensuring the safety and quality of the desired product. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods All the chemical reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used as received unless otherwise indicated. 2.1.1 Preparation of silica microspheres Solution A was obtained by mixing ethanol (16 mL), deionized water (24 mL) and 28 % ammonia (9 mL). Solution B was obtained by mixing ethanol (45 mL) and ethyl orthosilicate (5 mL). Solution B was quickly added to the solution A, stirring at 1100 rpm for 1 min, and then stirring at room temperature (400 rpm) for 2 h. Then the silica microspheres (SMs, 1.3 g) were collected by centrifugation and washing with ethanol three times before drying. 2.1.2 5 % metal modified silica microspheres Solution of SMs (3.0 g), 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES, 6 mL), and ethanol (100 mL) were stirred (1200 rpm) at 80 °C for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the modified SM (2.9 g) were obtained by centrifugation and washing with ethanol and ultrapure water for three times before drying. The modified SM (1.0 g), soluble metal salts (modifier, x mg) and deionized water (80 mL) was added to the hydrothermal synthesis kettle. Then the hydrothermal synthesis kettle was put into an oven at 120 °C for 24 h. 5 % metal-modified SMs were obtained by centrifugation and washing with ethanol and water before drying (for details, see Table S1 in Supporting Information). 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The morphology and element distribution of SMs were examined by scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi S4800 and Regulus 8100) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-2010 UHR). The XRD diffraction patterns were obtained from XD6 X-ray diffractometer (Beijing General Instrument Co., Ltd) with monochromatic Co Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 A°) at 36 kV and 20 mA in the 2θ scan range of 10-80° Functional group structures of the surface modified silica microsphere catalysts were observed by Flourier transform infrared (FT-IR, Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS5). The valence states of elements in the surface modified silica microsphere catalysts were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using Thermo K-Alpha XPS. 3 Results and discussion The silica microspheres used in this experiment were synthesized by Stöber method [53,54], and the SMs were modified by Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, and named SM-b. As shown in Fig. 2 , the SEM and TEM images of SM-b revealed that the SiO2 microspheres were uniform in diameter (ca. 0.4 μm). Copper species, measuring 20 nm in size, were loaded on the surface of silica microspheres without aggregation. Moreover, they were distributed on silica microspheres, resulting in a slightly rough surface. The XRD diffractogram of SM-b are shown in Fig. 3 a, and the characteristic diffraction peak at 23 °C belongs to SiO2 [55,56]. Furthermore, XPS analysis confirmed that the copper content on the surface of silica microspheres was only 1.3 wt% (Table S2). Consequently, due to the low copper content and its dispersed nature on the SiO2 surface, no crystalline structure was detected in the XRD diffractogram. As a result, the reaction could occur specifically and efficiently, avoiding the side reactions of diazo compounds [57].The SEM and TEM images of SM-b also confirmed this phenomenon. As shown in Fig. 3b, we tested fresh and used SM-b catalysts by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR). The peaks at 1100, 801, and 470 cm−1 could be attributed to the vibrations of Si–O–Si bonds. The wide vibration peak around 3440 cm−1 is assigned to ν (Si–OH) and ν (O–H) in the absorbed water, and the peak at 1634 cm−1 was attributed to δ (O–H) in water (ν = stretching vibration, δ = bending vibration) [58–60]. Notably, no bands appeared after the catalyst was used, manifesting that the structure of the SM-b catalyst was stable and reusable. The XPS spectra of the initial SM-b catalyst (Fig. 3c) reveal the presence of two distinct contributions at approximately 955.5 and 935.5 eV, which can be attributed to Cu(II) species. Additionally, there are observable peaks in the energy range of 963.0 and 943.0 eV, corresponding to the shake-up satellite of Cu(II) [61–64]. While Cu(I) and Cu(0) typically exhibits a binding energy around ∼ 932.0 eV, no clear peak appears at the corresponding position in the XPS spectra [65,66]. Hence, we believe that Cu(II) is the sole species present in the SM-b catalyst. Furthermore, the XPS analysis of the catalyst after the reaction (Figure S5) shows that the peaks at approximately 955.5 and 935.5 eV were consistent with Cu(II) species, maintaining their oxidation states. These results indicate that the oxidation states of copper remained unchanged during the reaction and Cu(II) species serve as the real catalytic centers. Initially, we selected diazo compounds 1a (methyl 2-diazo-2-phenylacetate) and carbazole 2a as model substrates to evaluate the feasibility of insertion reaction (Table S3 in Supporting Information). After screening catalysts, solvents, and temperature, the insertion reaction conditions were established to 50 mg SM-b as the catalyst, DCE as the solvent, 80 °C under an air atmosphere. Subsequently, to assess the impact of the silica microsphere particle size on catalytic performance, we successfully prepared SMs with sizes of 150 nm and 400 nm (Figure S2). These SMs were then modified with copper and employed as catalysts to afford the target products in similar yields, showing that the particle size of the catalyst did not significantly impact catalytic activity (Table S5). We then examined the generality of the N–H insertion reaction with a variety of α-diazoesters (Scheme 2 ). Different ester groups tolerated this reaction under the present conditions to deliver the corresponding products 3b-3e in 49–93 % yields. Moreover, the phenyl rings of α-diazoesters attached with a series of groups, including halogen (F, Cl, and Br), Me, and OMe, were well tolerated and furnished 3f-3 h, 3j, and 3 k in good to excellent yields (69–93 %). Clearly, lower yield was observed when withdrawing group trifluoromethyl was employed, providing 3i in 52 % yield. And the steric hindrance group dichloro substituted phenyl also lead to the reduction of yield to 61 % (3 l). When bulky 2-naphthyl-based diazo compound was used as the substrate, the reaction also proceeded smoothly to form 3n in 85 % yield. Delightfully, the antiphlogistic drug, carprofen, could achieve N–H functionalization via this reaction system to produce product 3o in 40 % yield, which proved its application potential in drug research and development. Next, we further investigated N-heterocycles and found that fused aryl and heteroaryl ring-functionalized N-substituted carbazoles (3p-3r) were also obtained in yields ranging from 53 % to 78 %. Additionally, we expanded the substrate scope to include indole derivatives. Fortunately, the SM catalyst still exhibited activity towards this type of substrate, resulting in target products (3 s-3v) with relatively lower yields (19–35 %). These relatively low yields can be attributed to the limited solubility of the indole substrate in DCE. Tetrahydroquinoline could also be used in this reaction to yield the product 3w in a 32 % yield. Regarding more anilines and thiophenols, these substrates also displayed decent reactivity in this catalytic system, providing the desired products 3x-3z and 3z1-3z3 in yields ranging from 41 % to 65 %. Finally, we used other types of carbene sources (N-tosylhydrazone, phenyliodonium ylide, and triazole) to verify the generality of this insertion reaction and found that N-tosylhydrazone could serve as a carbene precursor, reacting with 2a to yield the target product in a 22 % yield (eq 1). Given the diverse applications of organosilanes, we questioned whether heterogeneous SM catalyst could also apply in Si–H insertion reaction (Scheme 3 ). Gratifyingly, the present condition proved to be appropriate for our purpose, giving the C–Si bond product 5a in 93 % yield within 25 min (for details, see Table S4 in Supporting Information). Therefore, we examined a variety of α-diazoesters reacting with triethylsilane 4a, generating the target products 5b-5e in moderate to excellent yields (70–91 %). In addition, reacting 1,1,3,3-tetramethyldisiloxane with 1a, only the single C–Si bond product 5f was formed in 80 % yield and a trace of two C–Si bond product 5f' was detected, which due to the large steric hindrance. Then, the reaction of dimethyl(phenyl)silane with 1a was carried out smoothly in 12 min to effectively afford the desired product 5 g in 92 % yield. The triisopropylsilane also could react well with 1a, getting 5 h in moderate yield. Similarity, N-tosylhydrazone 1a' could also be used as carbene precursor in Si–H insertion reaction, generating the target product in 27 % yield (eq 2). To demonstrate the potential industrial application of the metal-modified SM catalysts, gram-scale preparation experiments were conducted. As shown in Scheme 4 a, 1a with carbazole 2a and triethylsilane 4a efficiently generated the N–H insertion product 3a in 71 % yield (0.86 g) and Si–H insertion product 5a in 70 % yield (1.05 g). To investigate whether copper was released from the SMs during the reaction, a thermal filtration experiment was performed. After the reaction continued for 1 h, the SM was filtered and high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) analysis revealed complete suppression of the reaction (for details, see Figure S4 in Supporting Information). Furthermore, we performed ICP analysis on the product (3a) and the reaction solution (Scheme 4b). Copper was not detected in the isolated product 3a and copper content is just 6.25 ppm in the reaction solution. For comparison, we selected a similar N–H insertion reaction in the literature [67], with 5 mol% CuPF6(MeCN)4 as the catalyst. The resulting copper in the product 3a' was 3174 ppm, (the FDA limit of Cu is 30 ppm) [68], and the residual copper in the solution was difficult to recover and reuse. Additionally, we investigated the reusability of the heterogenous catalyst SM-b. Results indicated that the performance of SM-b was not altered when used over seven subsequent reactions (Scheme 4c). These experiments confirmed that the reaction occurred on the surface of SMs. Moreover, we also compared the turnover number (TON) of SM-b with homogeneous copper salts or heterogeneous metal-modified catalysts (Table S9 in Supporting Information). It is noteworthy that SM-b exhibited a relatively high TON, further confirming its potential for industrial applications. Furthermore, some control experiments for the potential deactivation mechanisms of the catalyst were conducted. Firstly, we have investigated the catalyst's stability under various challenging conditions, including high temperatures, exposure to strong reductant, oxidant, and strong base (Scheme S1 in Supporting Information). It should be noted that when strong base was added, the silica microspheres carrier was etched. Subsequently, to assess the stability of the catalysts, we performed the N−H insertion reactions under standard conditions and found that the treated catalysts exhibited consistent catalytic activity, yielding the target products in high yields (entries 2–4, Table S11). These phenomena suggested that the catalyst could maintain catalytic activity under high temperature, strong reducing, or strong oxidizing conditions. To gain insight into the possible reaction mechanism, we performed several control experiments. Under the standard condition, the yields of product decreased when the reaction was performed by addition of 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine 1-oxyl (TEMPO), which may be due to the formation of copper complex between Cu(II) species and TEMPO on the surface of catalyst [69–71]. Whereas the reactions occurred smoothly in the presence of butylated hydroxytoluene (BHT) as radical trapper. These observations indicate that radicals are not involved in the insertion transformations (for details, see SI 9.1 in Supporting Information). Then, we performed a series of deuterium isotope exchange experiments to investigate the origin of the α-hydrogen atom in the product (Scheme 4d). Using D2O as additive, we obtained the N–H insertion product 3a-D with 55 % deuterium incorporation. In the dry DCE with 3Å molecular sieve, the reaction could also occur smoothly to afford 3a in 83 % yield, showing water is not required in this reaction. Then, deuterium exchange experiment using carbazole 2a and D2O as starting materials was performed, and in this case, we did not obtain N-deuteration product 2a-D. Collectively, these results indicated that the α-hydrogen atom in N-substituted carbazoles was originated from the carbazole and water. These phenomena suggested the N–H insertion reaction is likely going through a proton-shift process. While the reaction of diazo compound 1a with triethylsilane 4a in the presence of D2O did not afford the deuterium-labelled product 5a-D, suggesting the α-hydrogen atom was only originated from the silane. Finally, ylide trap experiments (Scheme 4e) were carried out using diazo compounds 1a with carbazole 2a or triethylsilane 4a in the presence of a trapping agent diisopropyl azodiformate (DIAD). For the N–H insertion reaction, the trapped N-ylide intermediate was identified through HRMS. In contrast, for the Si–H insertion reaction, no reactive intermediate was trapped, demonstrating that the insertion of Si–H bonds proceeds through a concerted mechanism (for details, see SI 9.3 in Supporting Information). Based on the above experiments and previous literature [21,72–76], we concluded the plausible mechanisms for the insertion reactions of diazo compounds (Scheme 4f). Initially, the diazo compound was decomposed through the combination of negatively polarized carbon with SM-b catalyst along with releasing molecular nitrogen to generate the copper carbene species, InA. For N–H insertion, the electron-deficient copper carbene was inserted into carbazole according to ylide generation. Then, with the departure of the SM catalyst, the N-ylide intermediate (InC) was generated. Finally, the product of 3a was obtained via proton-shift process. For Si–H insertion, the electrophilic copper carbene species reacted with silane to form the three-centered transition state, InD. Next, the carbene fragment was inserted into the Si–H bond, producing an organosilane (5a). Additionally, in the two-insertion reaction, the SM-b catalyst could be regenerated without loss of activity. 4 Conclusion In summary, we successfully designed and prepared metal-modified SMs via simple methods. These SMs can be applied in N–H and Si–H insertion reactions to efficiently generate N-substituted carbazoles and organosilanes. Dispersions of loaded metal complex can be envisaged by TEM and XRD experiments, revealing that all the metal salts are well dispersed on SMs surface. Moreover, gram-scale reactions and catalyst recycling reactions are amenable. The catalyst could be recycled and reused seven times without any substantial loss of catalytic activity, demonstrating the practical utility of surface modified SM catalysts. ICP analysis revealed that the residual metal level was only 6.25 ppm in the solution and was not detected in the product, which indicates that the catalyst is fully compatible with FDA-imposed specification. We believe that this work may provide feasible industrial applications for modified SMs. CRediT authorship contribution statement Haodong Xie: Data curation, Formal analysis, Writing – original draft. coredata.dc:description: Carbenes are key precursors for various transformations and are applied broadly in the synthesis of complex molecules and drug. Typically, such transformations require expensive metal and complex ligands, leading to a vigorous reaction system and trace metal residues. Herein, we report copper-modified silica microspheres (SM-b) as heterogeneous catalyst in the insertion reaction of diazo compounds with carbazole and silanes. Under this strategy, the optimal SM-b catalyst can prevent the reaction from being too vigorous and can be reused in continuous reactions. Furthermore, gram-scale and catalyst recycling reactions have been proven as the potential industrial applications of the SM-b catalysts. Inductively coupled plasma analysis revealed a residual copper content of only 6.25 ppm in the reaction solution and no detectable copper in the final product, indicating that the residual metal content of the product is far below the FDA-imposed limit of metal impurities.
coredata.dc:title: A stable Copper-Modified silica microsphere catalyst for the synthesis of N-substituted carbazoles and organosilanes
